grape.general_graph.GeneralGraph¶

class GeneralGraph(incoming_graph_data=None, **attr)[source]¶

Class GeneralGraph for directed graphs (DiGraph).

Constructs a new graph given an input file. A DiGraph stores nodes and edges with optional data or attributes. DiGraphs hold directed edges. Nodes can be arbitrary python objects with optional key/value attributes. Edges are represented as links between nodes with optional key/value attributes.

Initialize a graph with edges, name, or graph attributes.

Parameters

  • incoming_graph_data (input graph (optional, default: None)) – Data to initialize graph. If None (default) an empty graph is created. The data can be an edge list, or any NetworkX graph object. If the corresponding optional Python packages are installed the data can also be a NumPy matrix or 2d ndarray, a SciPy sparse matrix, or a PyGraphviz graph.

  • attr (keyword arguments, optional (default= no attributes)) – Attributes to add to graph as key=value pairs.

See also

convert

Examples

>>> G = nx.Graph()   # or DiGraph, MultiGraph, MultiDiGraph, etc
>>> G = nx.Graph(name='my graph')
>>> e = [(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)] # list of edges
>>> G = nx.Graph(e)

Arbitrary graph attribute pairs (key=value) may be assigned

>>> G = nx.Graph(e, day="Friday")
>>> G.graph
{'day': 'Friday'}
__init__(incoming_graph_data=None, **attr)¶

Initialize a graph with edges, name, or graph attributes.

Parameters

  • incoming_graph_data (input graph (optional, default: None)) – Data to initialize graph. If None (default) an empty graph is created. The data can be an edge list, or any NetworkX graph object. If the corresponding optional Python packages are installed the data can also be a NumPy matrix or 2d ndarray, a SciPy sparse matrix, or a PyGraphviz graph.

  • attr (keyword arguments, optional (default= no attributes)) – Attributes to add to graph as key=value pairs.

See also

convert()

Examples

>>> G = nx.Graph()   # or DiGraph, MultiGraph, MultiDiGraph, etc
>>> G = nx.Graph(name='my graph')
>>> e = [(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)] # list of edges
>>> G = nx.Graph(e)

Arbitrary graph attribute pairs (key=value) may be assigned

>>> G = nx.Graph(e, day="Friday")
>>> G.graph
{'day': 'Friday'}

Methods

__init__([incoming_graph_data])

Initialize a graph with edges, name, or graph attributes.

add_edge(u_of_edge, v_of_edge, **attr)

Add an edge between u and v.

add_edges_from(ebunch_to_add, **attr)

Add all the edges in ebunch_to_add.

add_node(node_for_adding, **attr)

Add a single node node_for_adding and update node attributes.

add_nodes_from(nodes_for_adding, **attr)

Add multiple nodes.

add_weighted_edges_from(ebunch_to_add[, weight])

Add weighted edges in ebunch_to_add with specified weight attr

adjacency()

Returns an iterator over (node, adjacency dict) tuples for all nodes.

betweenness_centrality()

Betweenness_centrality measure of each node.

calculate_shortest_path()

Choose the most appropriate way to compute the all-pairs shortest path depending on graph size and density.

check_after()

Describe the topology of the potentially perturbed graph, after the occurrence of a perturbation in the system.

check_before()

Describe the topology of the integer graph, before the occurrence of any perturbation in the system.

check_input_with_gephi()

Write list of nodes and list of edges csv files to visualize the input with Gephi.

chunk_it(nodi, n)

Divide graph nodes in chunks according to number of processes.

clear()

Remove all nodes and edges from the graph.

closeness_centrality()

Closeness_centrality measure of each node.

Inner iteration for parallel efficiency calculation, to update shared dictionary.

compute_efficiency_kernel(nodi)

Compute efficiency, starting from path length attribute.

Reconstruct source-target paths starting from predecessors matrix.

construct_path_iteration_parallel(pred, …)

Inner iteration for parallel Floyd Warshall APSP algorithm, to update shared dictionary.

construct_path_kernel(pred, nodi)

Populate the dictionary of shortest paths.

copy([as_view])

Returns a copy of the graph.

degree_centrality()

Degree centrality measure of each node.

delete_a_node(node)

Delete a node in the graph to simulate a perturbation to an element in a plant and start to propagate the perturbation.

edge_subgraph(edges)

Returns the subgraph induced by the specified edges.

Initialization of Floyd Warshall APSP algorithm.

Floyd Warshall’s APSP inner iteration.

Parallel Floyd Warshall’s APSP algorithm.

floyd_warshall_predecessor_and_distance_serial()

Serial Floyd Warshall’s APSP algorithm.

Returns the attribute dictionary associated with edge (u, v).

global_efficiency()

Average global efficiency of the whole graph.

graph_characterization_to_file(filename)

Write to file graph characterization after the perturbation.

has_edge(u, v)

Returns True if the edge (u, v) is in the graph.

has_node(n)

Returns True if the graph contains the node n.

has_predecessor(u, v)

Returns True if node u has predecessor v.

has_successor(u, v)

Returns True if node u has successor v.

Indegree centrality measure of each node.

is_directed()

Returns True if graph is directed, False otherwise.

is_multigraph()

Returns True if graph is a multigraph, False otherwise.

load(filename)

Load input file.

local_efficiency()

Local efficiency of the node.

merge_lists(l1, l2, key)

Merge two lists of dictionaries according to their keys.

nbunch_iter([nbunch])

Returns an iterator over nodes contained in nbunch that are also in the graph.

neighbors(n)

Returns an iterator over successor nodes of n.

nodal_efficiency()

Global efficiency of the node.

number_of_edges([u, v])

Returns the number of edges between two nodes.

number_of_nodes()

Returns the number of nodes in the graph.

Returns the number of nodes in the graph.

outdegree_centrality()

Outdegree centrality measure of each node.

parallel_wrapper_proc()

Wrapper for parallel SSSP algorithm based on Dijkstra’s method.

Returns an iterator over predecessor nodes of n.

Remove the edge between u and v.

remove_edges_from(ebunch)

Remove all edges specified in ebunch.

remove_node(n)

Remove node n.

remove_nodes_from(nodes)

Remove multiple nodes.

reverse([copy])

Returns the reverse of the graph.

rm_nodes(node[, visited])

Remove nodes from the graph in a depth first search way to propagate the perturbation.

service_paths_to_file(filename)

Write to file the service paths situation after the perturbation.

simulate_multi_area_perturbation(multi_areas)

Simulate a perturbation in one or multiple areas.

single_source_shortest_path_parallel(out_q, nodi)

Parallel SSSP algorithm based on Dijkstra’s method.

single_source_shortest_path_serial()

Serial SSSP algorithm based on Dijkstra’s method.

size([weight])

Returns the number of edges or total of all edge weights.

subgraph(nodes)

Returns a SubGraph view of the subgraph induced on nodes.

successors(n)

Returns an iterator over successor nodes of n.

to_directed([as_view])

Returns a directed representation of the graph.

to_directed_class()

Returns the class to use for empty directed copies.

to_undirected([reciprocal, as_view])

Returns an undirected representation of the digraph.

to_undirected_class()

Returns the class to use for empty undirected copies.

update([edges, nodes])

Update the graph using nodes/edges/graphs as input.

update_areas(multi_areas)

Update the status of the elements in the areas after the propagation of the perturbation.

update_status(which_status, field, …)

Update the status of the nodes not concerned by the perturbation.

Attributes

adj

Graph adjacency object holding the neighbors of each node.

degree

A DegreeView for the Graph as G.degree or G.degree().

edges

An OutEdgeView of the DiGraph as G.edges or G.edges().

in_degree

An InDegreeView for (node, in_degree) or in_degree for single node.

in_edges

An InEdgeView of the Graph as G.in_edges or G.in_edges().

name

String identifier of the graph.

nodes

A NodeView of the Graph as G.nodes or G.nodes().

out_degree

An OutDegreeView for (node, out_degree)

out_edges

An OutEdgeView of the DiGraph as G.edges or G.edges().

pred

Graph adjacency object holding the predecessors of each node.

succ

Graph adjacency object holding the successors of each node.
